articles.headline: As Neo-Nazis Seed Military Ranks, Germany Confronts ‘an Enemy Within’
articles.snippet: After plastic explosives and Nazi memorabilia were found at an elite soldier’s home, Germany worries about a problem of far-right infiltration at the heart of its democracy.
articles.abstract: After plastic explosives and Nazi memorabilia were found at an elite soldier’s home, Germany worries about a problem of far-right infiltration at the heart of its democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALW, Germany — As Germany emerged from its coronavirus lockdown in May, police commandos pulled up outside a rural property owned by a sergeant major in the special forces, the country’s most highly trained and secretive military unit.

articles.headline: European Workers Draw Paychecks. American Workers Scrounge for Food.
articles.snippet: In the pandemic, the United States has relied on expanded unemployment benefits, while European governments have subsidized wages, avoiding a surge in joblessness.
articles.abstract: In the pandemic, the United States has relied on expanded unemployment benefits, while European governments have subsidized wages, avoiding a surge in joblessness.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the southeast corner of Ireland, Brian Byrne’s event-planning business was confronting a calamity. It was the middle of March, and the coronavirus pandemic was nearing peak lethality. As the government barred gatherings like music festivals, his revenue disappeared, forcing him to consider laying off his four full-time workers.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Patricia Cohen and Rachel Chaundler

articles.headline: ‘They Have Lost Control’: Why Minneapolis Burned
articles.snippet: After George Floyd’s death, pent-up frustrations, provocateurs and inexperienced leadership led to mayhem for three nights.
articles.abstract: After George Floyd’s death, pent-up frustrations, provocateurs and inexperienced leadership led to mayhem for three nights.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two days after George Floyd died, the police chief of Minneapolis called the mayor around dinnertime. He needed help. What had begun as peaceful protests outside the Third Police Precinct was turning into mayhem.

articles.headline: Trump Uses Mount Rushmore Speech to Deliver Divisive Culture War Message
articles.snippet: Down in the polls and failing to control a raging pandemic, the president cast himself as waging battle against a “new far-left fascism” that imperils American values and seeks to erase history.
articles.abstract: Down in the polls and failing to control a raging pandemic, the president cast himself as waging battle against a “new far-left fascism” that imperils American values and seeks to erase history.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Standing in a packed amphitheater in front of Mount Rushmore for an Independence Day celebration, President Trump delivered a dark and divisive speech on Friday that cast his struggling effort to win a second term as a battle against a “new far-left fascism” seeking to wipe out the nation’s values and history.

articles.headline: Virus Surges in Arizona, but the Rodeo Goes On
articles.snippet: A former state official called what has happened in Arizona “a story of missed opportunities.” Hospital beds in the state are filling up.
articles.abstract: A former state official called what has happened in Arizona “a story of missed opportunities.” Hospital beds in the state are filling up.

articles.headline: This Year’s Summer Campground: Our Bedrooms and Living Rooms
articles.snippet: Summer camp in the pandemic looks just like a screen. But what happens when kids run away from the computer?
articles.abstract: Summer camp in the pandemic looks just like a screen. But what happens when kids run away from the computer?
articles.lead_paragraph: Children at Interlochen Arts Camp in Michigan are doing all the usual this summer. They are taking dance and acting classes, learning to tie knots and weaving friendship bracelets. On some days, they sing campfire songs.

articles.headline: How the Republican Convention Created Money Woes in Two Cities
articles.snippet: Donors are wondering why they gave to a Charlotte event that has mostly been scrapped. And Jacksonville fund-raisers find money is on hold because of concerns about the surge in virus cases.
articles.abstract: Donors are wondering why they gave to a Charlotte event that has mostly been scrapped. And Jacksonville fund-raisers find money is on hold because of concerns about the surge in virus cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: Trump abruptly cancels Republican Convention in Jacksonville.]
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Rebecca R. Ruiz and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: In West Texas, Lingering Distrust in Public Health Measures as Virus Spreads
articles.snippet: Early in the pandemic, much of rural Texas had low case counts and few worries. Now, conservative areas are seeing a surge in cases, but distrust in government mandates endures.
articles.abstract: Early in the pandemic, much of rural Texas had low case counts and few worries. Now, conservative areas are seeing a surge in cases, but distrust in government mandates endures.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUBBOCK, Texas — For a while, it seemed that the coronavirus had spared West Texas. Cases were low. Few had died. Concern through the spring was focused on getting businesses running again.

articles.headline: As Coronavirus Slams Houston Hospitals, It’s Like New York ‘All Over Again’
articles.snippet: The death toll is lower, but there are echoes of March as cases spike, doctors fall ill and supplies run short. Now, Texas is trying to adapt hard-won lessons while addressing a new set of challenges.
articles.abstract: The death toll is lower, but there are echoes of March as cases spike, doctors fall ill and supplies run short. Now, Texas is trying to adapt hard-won lessons while addressing a new set of challenges.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Over the past week, Dr. Aric Bakshy, an emergency physician at Houston Methodist, had to decide which coronavirus patients he should admit to the increasingly busy hospital and which he could safely send home.

articles.headline: At Mt. Rushmore and the White House, Trump Updates ‘American Carnage’ Message for 2020
articles.snippet: His ominous remarks were a reflection of his political standing: trailing in the polls, lacking a booming economy or a positive message to campaign on, and leaning on culture wars to buoy his loyalists.
articles.abstract: His ominous remarks were a reflection of his political standing: trailing in the polls, lacking a booming economy or a positive message to campaign on, and leaning on culture wars to buoy his loyalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump used the spotlight of the Fourth of July weekend to sow division during a national crisis, denying his failings in containing the worsening coronavirus pandemic while delivering a harsh diatribe against what he branded the “new far-left fascism.”
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Hong Kong, Changed Overnight, Navigates Its New Reality
articles.snippet: In a city where China has made some ideas suddenly dangerous, people are trying to figure out where the boundaries lie, and how their lives have changed.
articles.abstract: In a city where China has made some ideas suddenly dangerous, people are trying to figure out where the boundaries lie, and how their lives have changed.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A barge draped with enormous red banners celebrating China’s new security law was sailing across Hong Kong’s famed Victoria Harbor only hours after the legislation passed. The police now hoist a purple sign warning protesters that their chants could be criminal. Along major roads throughout the city, neon-colored flags hailing a new era of stability and prosperity stand erect as soldiers.
articles.byline: By Vivian Wang, Elaine Yu and Tiffany May

articles.headline: China Dominates Medical Supplies, in This Outbreak and the Next
articles.snippet: Government support and protectionism have built a low-cost industry making masks, testing kits and other health gear. Other countries will find it tough to compete.
articles.abstract: Government support and protectionism have built a low-cost industry making masks, testing kits and other health gear. Other countries will find it tough to compete.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Alarmed at China’s stranglehold over supplies of masks, gowns, test kits and other front-line weapons for battling the coronavirus, countries around the world have set up their own factories to cope with this pandemic and outbreaks of the future.

articles.headline: The Fullest Look Yet at the Racial Inequity of Coronavirus
articles.snippet: New federal data provides the most comprehensive view to date of how Black and Latino people have been likelier than their white peers to contract the virus and die from it.
articles.abstract: New federal data provides the most comprehensive view to date of how Black and Latino people have been likelier than their white peers to contract the virus and die from it.
articles.lead_paragraph: New federal data provides the most comprehensive view to date of how Black and Latino people have been likelier than their white peers to contract the virus and die from it.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr., Robert Gebeloff, K.K. Rebecca Lai, Will Wright and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Chicago Gun Violence Spikes and Increasingly Finds the Youngest Victims
articles.snippet: Nine children under the age of 18 have been shot dead in Chicago since June 20.
articles.abstract: Nine children under the age of 18 have been shot dead in Chicago since June 20.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Yasmin Miller drove home from a laundromat in Chicago’s Englewood neighborhood last weekend, a gunman in another car peppered her red Hyundai sedan with bullets, grazing her head and striking her son, Sincere Gaston, in the chest. Sincere died in his car seat. He was 20 months old.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Robert Chiarito

articles.headline: ‘Strategic Empathy’: How Biden’s Informal Diplomacy Shaped Foreign Relations
articles.snippet: President Trump is attacking his record on China. But for Mr. Biden, it’s part of a long history of befriending and sometimes confronting world leaders.
articles.abstract: President Trump is attacking his record on China. But for Mr. Biden, it’s part of a long history of befriending and sometimes confronting world leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Barack Obama had a China problem. His national security team knew the Chinese Communist Party was getting ready to anoint a new leader. But his aides wanted to better understand the man they expected to assume power, Xi Jinping. It seemed like a job for Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.

articles.headline: How Netflix Beat Hollywood to a Generation of Black Content
articles.snippet: The company didn’t set out to build a big library of Black programming, but now it’s the envy of its rivals.
articles.abstract: The company didn’t set out to build a big library of Black programming, but now it’s the envy of its rivals.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Black documentarian Stanley Nelson says his phone has been “ringing off the hook” as America is looking again at racism and the Black experience. Justin Simien, the creator of “Dear White People,” says the reactions to his pitches have grown warmer. And the director Ava DuVernay reports a flood of calls to “me and every other Black person that’s ever picked up a camera.”

articles.headline: Trump Vowed to ‘Drain the Swamp,’ but Lobbyists Are Helping Run His Campaign
articles.snippet: Lobbyists like David Urban, whose connections start at the very top, are thriving as they help the president’s re-election effort while aiding corporate clients.
articles.abstract: Lobbyists like David Urban, whose connections start at the very top, are thriving as they help the president’s re-election effort while aiding corporate clients.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The chief executive of the arms maker Raytheon, under pressure to overcome a congressional hold on major sales in the fall of 2018, wanted to sit down with one of the few people who could solve the problem — Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel, Michael LaForgia and Hailey Fuchs

articles.headline: As the Virus Surged, Florida Partied. Tracking the Revelers Has Been Tough.
articles.snippet: With the coronavirus exploding, trying to trace the contacts of every positive case has become unrealistic in Florida, especially among elusive partygoers.
articles.abstract: With the coronavirus exploding, trying to trace the contacts of every positive case has become unrealistic in Florida, especially among elusive partygoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Miami’s flashy nightclubs closed in March, but the parties have raged on in the waterfront manse tucked in the lush residential neighborhood of Belle Meade Island. Revelers arrive in sports cars and ride-shares several nights a week, say neighbors who have spied professional bouncers at the door and bought earplugs to try to sleep through the thumping dance beats.

articles.headline: Our Cash-Free Future Is Getting Closer
articles.snippet: The pandemic is propelling a shift toward a cashless society in ways that no other single event has. Experts say that’s not necessarily a good thing.
articles.abstract: The pandemic is propelling a shift toward a cashless society in ways that no other single event has. Experts say that’s not necessarily a good thing.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — On a typical Sunday, patrons at Julien Cornu’s cheese shop used to load up on Camembert and chèvre for the week, with about half the customers digging into their pockets for euro notes and coins.

articles.headline: The Next Energy Battle: Renewables vs. Natural Gas
articles.snippet: As coal declines and wind and solar energy rise, some are pushing to limit the use of natural gas, but utilities say they are not ready to do so.
articles.abstract: As coal declines and wind and solar energy rise, some are pushing to limit the use of natural gas, but utilities say they are not ready to do so.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dominion Energy, one of the nation’s largest utilities, in late June erected wind turbines off the Virginia coast — only the second such installation in the United States — as part of a big bet on renewable energy.

articles.headline: States May Curb ‘Faithless Electors,’ Supreme Court Rules
articles.snippet: The court said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
articles.abstract: The court said states may require members of the Electoral College to vote for the presidential candidates they had promised to support.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Read our 2020 presidential election electoral college explainer.]

articles.headline: Trump Adds to Playbook of Stoking White Fear and Resentment
articles.snippet: With a defense of Confederate flags and a false accusation against a Black NASCAR driver, Bubba Wallace, President Trump is focusing on racial and cultural flash points to appeal to his base.
articles.abstract: With a defense of Confederate flags and a false accusation against a Black NASCAR driver, Bubba Wallace, President Trump is focusing on racial and cultural flash points to appeal to his base.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump mounted an explicit defense of the Confederate flag on Monday, suggesting that NASCAR had made a mistake in banning it from its auto racing events, while falsely accusing a top Black driver, Darrell Wallace Jr., of perpetrating a hoax involving a noose found in his garage.

articles.headline: Lobbyists, Law Firms and Trade Groups Took Small-Business Loans
articles.snippet: The Trump administration began releasing details of which businesses received Paycheck Protection Program aid.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration began releasing details of which businesses received Paycheck Protection Program aid.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration, under pressure to reveal which companies received loans from a $660 billion program intended to keep small businesses afloat, on Monday released data showing that restaurants, medical offices and car dealerships ranked high among the top loan recipients.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek, Jim Tankersley and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: TikTok to Withdraw From Hong Kong as Tech Giants Halt Data Requests
articles.snippet: Google, Facebook and Twitter said they were reviewing China’s punitive new national security law for the city, a rare public questioning of Chinese policy by major American tech companies.
articles.abstract: Google, Facebook and Twitter said they were reviewing China’s punitive new national security law for the city, a rare public questioning of Chinese policy by major American tech companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google, Facebook and Twitter said on Monday that they would temporarily stop processing Hong Kong government requests for user data as the companies reviewed a sweeping national security law that has chilled political expression in the city.
